**Leslie Feist** (born 13 February 1976), known professionally as **Feist** ,
is a Canadian [indie pop](/wiki/Indie_pop "Indie pop") singer-songwriter and
guitarist,[2] performing both as a solo artist and as a member of the [indie
rock](/wiki/Indie_rock "Indie rock") group [Broken Social
Scene](/wiki/Broken_Social_Scene "Broken Social Scene").

Feist launched her solo music career in 1999 with the release of
_[Monarch](/wiki/Monarch_\(Lay_Your_Jewelled_Head_Down\) "Monarch \(Lay Your
Jewelled Head Down\)")_. Her subsequent studio albums, _[Let It
Die](/wiki/Let_It_Die_\(album\) "Let It Die \(album\)")_ , released in 2004,
and _[The Reminder](/wiki/The_Reminder "The Reminder")_ , released in 2007,
were critically acclaimed and commercially successful, selling over 2.5
million copies. _The Reminder_ earned Feist four Grammy nominations, including
a nomination for [Best New Artist](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_New_Artist
"Grammy Award for Best New Artist").[3] She has received 11 Juno Awards,
including two Artist of the Year.[4] Her fourth studio album,
_[Metals](/wiki/Metals_\(album\) "Metals \(album\)")_ , was released on 30
September 2011. In 2012, Feist collaborated on a split EP with metal group
[Mastodon](/wiki/Mastodon_\(band\) "Mastodon \(band\)"), releasing an
interactive music video in the process.[5]

Feist received three Juno awards at the 2012 ceremony: Artist of the Year,
Adult Alternative Album of the Year for _Metals_ , and Music DVD of the Year
for her documentary _[Look at What the Light Did
Now](/wiki/Look_at_What_the_Light_Did_Now "Look at What the Light Did
Now")_.[6]

## Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Feist_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early life")]

Leslie Feist was born on 13 February 1976 in [Amherst, Nova
Scotia](/wiki/Amherst,_Nova_Scotia "Amherst, Nova Scotia"), Canada. Her
parents are both artists. Her father, Harold Feist, is an American-Canadian
[abstract expressionist](/wiki/Abstract_expressionism "Abstract
expressionism") painter who taught at both the [Alberta College of Art and
Design](/wiki/Alberta_College_of_Art_and_Design "Alberta College of Art and
Design") and [Mount Allison University](/wiki/Mount_Allison_University "Mount
Allison University") in [Sackville, New
Brunswick](/wiki/Sackville,_New_Brunswick "Sackville, New
Brunswick").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Her mother, Lyn Feist, was a student of
[ceramics](/wiki/Ceramic "Ceramic") from Saskatchewan. After their first
child, Ben, was born, the family moved to Sackville.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Feist's parents divorced soon after she was born and Ben, Feist and their
mother moved to [Regina, Saskatchewan](/wiki/Regina,_Saskatchewan "Regina,
Saskatchewan"), where they lived with her grandparents. They later moved to
[Calgary, Alberta](/wiki/Calgary "Calgary"), where she attended [Bishop
Carroll High School](/wiki/Bishop_Carroll_High_School_\(Calgary,_Alberta\)
"Bishop Carroll High School \(Calgary, Alberta\)") as well as [Alternative
High School](/wiki/Alternative_High_School_\(Calgary\) "Alternative High
School \(Calgary\)"). She aspired to be a writer, and spent much of her youth
singing in choirs.[7] At the age of twelve, Feist performed as one of 1,000
dancers in the opening ceremonies of the [Calgary Winter
Olympics](/wiki/1988_Winter_Olympics "1988 Winter Olympics"), which she cites
as inspiration for the video "1234."

Because her father is American, Feist has dual Canadian-U.S. citizenship,[8]
joking later that she was given U.S. citizenship as part of a deal with
[Apple](/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.").[9][10]

## Music
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Feist_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Music career")]

In 1991, at age 15, Feist got her start in music when she founded and was the
lead vocalist for a Calgary punk band called Placebo (not to be confused with
the English band [Placebo](/wiki/Placebo_\(band\) "Placebo \(band\)")).[7][11]
She and her bandmates won a local Battle of the Bands competition and were
awarded the opening slot at the festival Infest 1993, featuring the Ramones.
At this concert she met [Brendan Canning](/wiki/Brendan_Canning "Brendan
Canning"), whose band [hHead](/wiki/HHead "HHead") performed immediately
before hers, and with whom she joined in [Broken Social
Scene](/wiki/Broken_Social_Scene "Broken Social Scene") ten years later.[12]

In 1995, Feist was forced to take time off from music to recover from vocal
cord damage. She moved from Calgary to Toronto in 1996. That year she was
asked by [Noah Mintz](/wiki/Noah_Mintz "Noah Mintz") of [hHead](/wiki/HHead
"HHead") to play bass in his solo project [Noah's
Arkweld](/wiki/Noah%27s_Arkweld "Noah's Arkweld"). She played the bass guitar
in Noah's Arkweld for a year despite never having played bass before. In 1998,
she became the rhythm guitarist for the band [By Divine
Right](/wiki/By_Divine_Right "By Divine Right") and toured with them
throughout 1998, 1999, and 2000. She also played guitar for some live
performances by [Bodega](/wiki/Bodega_\(Canadian_band\) "Bodega \(Canadian
band\)"), but was never an official member of the band.[13]

In 1999, Feist moved into a [Queen West](/wiki/Queen_Street_West "Queen Street
West") apartment above [Come As You Are](/wiki/Come_As_You_Are_\(sex_shop\)
"Come As You Are \(sex shop\)") with a friend of a friend, [Merrill
Nisker](/wiki/Merrill_Nisker "Merrill Nisker"), who then began to perform as
electro-punk musician [Peaches](/wiki/Peaches_\(musician\) "Peaches
\(musician\)").[14][15] Feist worked the back of the stage at Peaches' shows,
using a [sock puppet](/wiki/Sock_puppet "Sock puppet") and calling herself
"Bitch Lap Lap".[16] The two also toured together in England from 2000–2001,
staying with [Justine Frischmann](/wiki/Justine_Frischmann "Justine
Frischmann") of [Elastica](/wiki/Elastica "Elastica") and
[MIA](/wiki/M.I.A._\(artist\) "M.I.A. \(artist\)")[17] Feist appeared as a
guest vocalist on _[The Teaches of Peaches](/wiki/The_Teaches_of_Peaches "The
Teaches of Peaches")._ Feist appears in Peaches' video for the song
"[Lovertits](/wiki/Lovertits "Lovertits")", suggestively rubbing and licking a
bike. Later, Feist covered this song with
[Gonzales](/wiki/Gonzales_\(musician\) "Gonzales \(musician\)") (whom she met
while touring with Peaches) on her album _Open Season_. In 2006, Feist
contributed backup vocals on a track entitled "Give 'Er", which appeared on
[Peaches'](/wiki/Peaches_\(musician\) "Peaches \(musician\)") album _[Impeach
My Bush](/wiki/Impeach_My_Bush "Impeach My Bush")._

### _Monarch (Lay Your Jewelled Head Down)_
(1999-2001)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Feist_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Monarch \(Lay Your Jewelled Head Down\) \(1999-2001\)")]

Feist's solo debut album,
_[Monarch](/wiki/Monarch_\(Lay_Your_Jewelled_Head_Down\) "Monarch \(Lay Your
Jewelled Head Down\)"),_ was released in 1999. It is composed of ten songs,
including "Monarch" and "That's What I Say, It's Not What I Mean." The album
was produced by Dan Kurtz, who would later form [Dragonette](/wiki/Dragonette
"Dragonette").

### _Let It Die_
(2001-2006)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Feist_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Let It Die \(2001-2006\)")]

In the summer of 2001, Feist self-produced seven songs at home which she
called _The Red Demos,_ which have never been released commercially. She spent
more than two years touring throughout Europe with Gonzales. In that same year
she joined a group of old friends in forming a new version of Toronto indie
rock group [Broken Social Scene](/wiki/Broken_Social_Scene "Broken Social
Scene"), adding vocals to many tracks after being forbidden to play guitar by
de facto bandleader [Kevin Drew](/wiki/Kevin_Drew "Kevin Drew").[18] She
subsequently recorded _[You Forgot It in People](/wiki/You_Forgot_It_in_People
"You Forgot It in People")_ with the band. While on tour in Europe with
Gonzales, they began recording new versions of her home recorded _Red Demos,_
which would later become her major label debut _[Let It
Die](/wiki/Let_It_Die_\(album\) "Let It Die \(album\)")._ _Let It Die_
featured both original compositions and covers, and Feist has been noted both
as a songwriter and as an innovative interpreter of other artists' songs.

After the recording of _Let It Die,_ Feist moved to Paris. While in Europe,
she collaborated with Norwegian duo [Kings of
Convenience](/wiki/Kings_of_Convenience "Kings of Convenience") as co-writer
and guest vocalist on their album _[Riot on an Empty
Street](/wiki/Riot_on_an_Empty_Street "Riot on an Empty Street"),_ singing on
"Know How," and "The Build Up." She also co-wrote and sang "The Simple Story"
as a duet with [Jane Birkin](/wiki/Jane_Birkin "Jane Birkin") on her album
_Rendezvous._

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Feistportrait.jpg/170px-
Feistportrait.jpg)](/wiki/File:Feistportrait.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Feistportrait.jpg "Enlarge")

Feist in 2005

Feist toured during 2004, 2005 and 2006 through North America, Europe, Asia,
and Australia supporting _[Let It Die](/wiki/Let_It_Die_\(album\) "Let It Die
\(album\)")._ She won two Canadian [Juno Awards](/wiki/Juno_Award "Juno
Award") for "Best New Artist" and "Best Alternative Rock Album" in 2004. Sales
of _Let It Die_ totaled 500,000 internationally, and she was awarded a
platinum record in Canada, as well as a gold album in France. Fellow Canadian
[Buck 65](/wiki/Buck_65 "Buck 65") appeared in the Feist-directed music video
for "One Evening," which was also nominated for Video of the Year at the 2004
Juno Awards.

In 2005, Feist contributed to the [UNICEF](/wiki/UNICEF "UNICEF") benefit song
"[Do They Know It's Hallowe'en?](/wiki/Do_They_Know_It%27s_Hallowe%27en%3F "Do
They Know It's Hallowe'en?")" The track "[Mushaboom](/wiki/Mushaboom_\(song\)
"Mushaboom \(song\)")" was used in an advert for a Lacoste men's fragrance, as
well as in the film [500 Days of Summer](/wiki/500_Days_of_Summer "500 Days of
Summer").

An album of remixes and collaborations, _[Open
Season](/wiki/Open_Season_\(Feist_album\) "Open Season \(Feist album\)")_ ,
was released on 18 April 2006.

Feist also lent her voice to the two tracks "La Même Histoire" and "We're All
in the Dance" for the soundtrack to the 2006 film _[Paris, je
t'aime](/wiki/Paris,_je_t%27aime "Paris, je t'aime")._

### _The Reminder_
(2006-2007)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Feist_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: The Reminder \(2006-2007\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Leslie_Feist_at_the_filmore_in_SF.png/220px-
Leslie_Feist_at_the_filmore_in_SF.png)](/wiki/File:Leslie_Feist_at_the_filmore_in_SF.png)

[](/wiki/File:Leslie_Feist_at_the_filmore_in_SF.png "Enlarge")

Feist performing in 2006

In early 2006, Feist moved to Paris,[15] where she recorded a followup to _Let
It Die_ at LaFrette Studios with [Gonzales](/wiki/Gonzales_\(musician\)
"Gonzales \(musician\)"), [Mocky](/wiki/Mocky "Mocky"), [Jamie
Lidell](/wiki/Jamie_Lidell "Jamie Lidell"), and Renaud Letang, as well as her
touring band Bryden Baird, Jesse Baird, Julian Brown of [Apostle of
Hustle](/wiki/Apostle_of_Hustle "Apostle of Hustle"), and [Afie
Jurvanen](/wiki/Afie_Jurvanen "Afie Jurvanen") of Paso Mino.

Feist's third solo album, _[The Reminder](/wiki/The_Reminder "The Reminder"),_
was released on 23 April 2007 in Europe, and on 1 May 2007 in Canada, the USA,
and the rest of the world. She toured worldwide to promote the album.[19] The
album features "[1234](/wiki/1234_\(Feist_song\) "1234 \(Feist song\)")," a
song co-written by New Buffalo's [Sally Seltmann](/wiki/Sally_Seltmann "Sally
Seltmann"), that became a surprise hit after being featured in a commercial
for the [iPod nano](/wiki/IPod_nano "IPod nano"), hitting No. 8 in the US, a
rare feat for [indie rock](/wiki/Indie_rock "Indie rock") musicians and even
more notable since it hit the Top Ten on the strength of downloads alone. She
has been lauded in the press and was featured on the cover of the _New York
Times_ arts section in June 2007. _[The Reminder](/wiki/The_Reminder "The
Reminder")_ had sold worldwide over 1,000,000 copies and is certified gold in
the U.S.[20] The album also won a [2008 Juno Award](/wiki/Juno_Awards_of_2008
"Juno Awards of 2008") for ["Album of the
Year"](/wiki/Juno_Award_for_Album_of_the_Year "Juno Award for Album of the
Year") on 6 April 2008 in [Calgary, Alberta](/wiki/Calgary,_Alberta "Calgary,
Alberta").

Videos for many of the singles were directed by [Patrick
Daughters](/wiki/Patrick_Daughters "Patrick Daughters"), who previously
directed the video for "Mushaboom" and went on to direct "1234," "My Moon, My
Man," and "I Feel It All." "1234" and "My Moon, My Man" were choreographed by
the acclaimed choreographer & dancer [Noemie Lafrance](/wiki/Noemie_Lafrance
"Noemie Lafrance"). The video for _Honey, Honey_ features the work of avant-
garde puppet troupe, [The Old Trout Puppet
Workshop](/wiki/The_Old_Trout_Puppet_Workshop "The Old Trout Puppet
Workshop").

"[I Feel It All](/wiki/I_Feel_It_All "I Feel It All")" was featured in the UK
teen comedy _[The Inbetweeners](/wiki/The_Inbetweeners "The Inbetweeners")_
and was used in the film _[The Accidental
Husband](/wiki/The_Accidental_Husband "The Accidental Husband")_. "Honey
Honey" was featured in _[The L Word](/wiki/The_L_Word "The L Word")_ (episode
5.06, "Lights! Camera! Action!"). "I Feel It All" was featured in the 2008
film _[The Women](/wiki/The_Women_\(2008_film\) "The Women \(2008 film\)")_.
Popular German DJ [Boys Noize](/wiki/Boys_Noize "Boys Noize") remixed "My
Moon, My Man," which appears on his 2007 debut album _[Oi Oi
Oi](/wiki/Oi_Oi_Oi_\(album\) "Oi Oi Oi \(album\)")_. The DJ has also been
known to close sets with the remix. In January 2009, [Bon Iver](/wiki/Bon_Iver
"Bon Iver") played a cover of Feist's "The Park" from _The Reminder_ on
Australian radio's [Triple J](/wiki/Triple_J "Triple J"). The song "Limit to
Your Love" was featured in season 2, episode 1 of British teen drama
[Skins](/wiki/Skins_\(TV_series\) "Skins \(TV series\)"), and was used in the
film [The Accidental Husband](/wiki/The_Accidental_Husband "The Accidental
Husband"). A [cover version](/wiki/Limit_to_Your_Love "Limit to Your Love") of
the song was released by UK singer-producer [James
Blake](/wiki/James_Blake_\(musician\) "James Blake \(musician\)") as a single
from his 2011 self-titled album.

####
"1234"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Feist_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=6&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: "1234"")]

Main article: [1234 (Feist song)](/wiki/1234_\(Feist_song\) "1234 \(Feist
song\)")

Prior to the airing of an Apple iPod nano commercial featuring this song, _The
Reminder_ was selling at approximately 6,000 copies per week, and "1234" at
2,000 downloads per week. Following the commercial, the song passed 73,000
total downloads and reached No. 7 on Hot Digital Songs and No. 8 on the
Billboard Hot 100; _The Reminder_ jumped from No. 36 to No. 28 on the
Billboard 200, with sales of 19,000.[21] Following the television
advertisement for the iPod nano in the UK, the single beat its original chart
position of 102 to become number 8 in the UK charts.
_[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")_ magazine named "1234"
one of The 10 Best Songs of 2007, ranking it at No. 2. Writer [Josh
Tyrangiel](/wiki/Josh_Tyrangiel "Josh Tyrangiel") called the song a
"masterpiece," praising Feist for singing it "with a mixture of wisdom and
exuberance that's all her own".[22][23] On 6 April 2008, Feist won a [Juno
Award](/wiki/Juno_Awards_of_2008 "Juno Awards of 2008") for the single as
["Single of the Year"](/wiki/Juno_Award_for_Single_of_the_Year "Juno Award for
Single of the Year").

Feist performed an alternate version of "1234" on _[Sesame
Street](/wiki/Sesame_Street "Sesame Street")_ during its 39th season (2008),
teaching children to count to the number four.[24] She said working with the
Muppets was a career highlight.[25]

#### "The
Water"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Feist_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=7&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: "The Water"")]

In 2009, Feist appeared in a short film directed by Broken Social Scene
bandmate Kevin Drew that focused on her song "The Water." Feist appears
alongside [Cillian Murphy](/wiki/Cillian_Murphy "Cillian Murphy") and David
Fox in the silent role of "Mother." This film was streamed from Pitchfork.com
for a week starting on 2 March 2009. In an interview with the site, Feist
described the experience of being in this movie as "watching a movie while
being in a movie."[26]

### _Metals_
(2007-2013)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Feist_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=8&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Metals \(2007-2013\)")]

In 2007, Feist was placed No. 9 on Spinner.com's 2007 _Women Who Rock Right
Now_.[27] and named both [Spin](/wiki/Spin_\(magazine\) "Spin \(magazine\)")'s
and [Blender](/wiki/Blender_\(magazine\) "Blender \(magazine\)")'s Breakout
Artist of the Year.[28][29] After taking [Bob Wiseman](/wiki/Bob_Wiseman "Bob
Wiseman") on the road as her opening act in Europe she acted in his video _Who
Am I_ and joined him on drums for _You Don 't Love Me,_ both of which are
visible on YouTube.

Feist was photographed by [Annie Leibovitz](/wiki/Annie_Leibovitz "Annie
Leibovitz") for the November 2007 issue of _[Vanity
Fair](/wiki/Vanity_Fair_\(magazine\) "Vanity Fair \(magazine\)")_ as part of a
photo essay on folk music.[30] On 3 November that year, she performed
"[1234](/wiki/1234_\(Feist_song\) "1234 \(Feist song\)")" and "[I Feel It
All](/wiki/I_Feel_It_All "I Feel It All")" on _[Saturday Night
Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")_.[31]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Feist_Festival_d%27%C3%89t%C3%A9_de_Qu%C3%A9bec_2008.jpg/170px-
Feist_Festival_d%27%C3%89t%C3%A9_de_Qu%C3%A9bec_2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:Feist_Festival_d%27%C3%89t%C3%A9_de_Qu%C3%A9bec_2008.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Feist_Festival_d%27%C3%89t%C3%A9_de_Qu%C3%A9bec_2008.jpg
"Enlarge")

Feist live at the [Festival d'été de Québec](/wiki/Quebec_City_Summer_Festival
"Quebec City Summer Festival") 2008 ([Québec](/wiki/Quebec_City "Quebec
City"), Canada)

Feist was on the cover of the Spring 2008 edition of _[Naked
Eye](/wiki/Naked_Eye_\(magazine\) "Naked Eye \(magazine\)")_. On 28 April,
Feist was interviewed by [Stephen Colbert](/wiki/Stephen_Colbert "Stephen
Colbert"). At the end of the show she performed "I Feel It All," while Colbert
donned Feist's blue, sequined, strapless jumpsuit from the
"[1234](/wiki/1234_\(Feist_song\) "1234 \(Feist song\)")" video. Feist joined
Colbert again on his first-ever Christmas special, _[A Colbert Christmas: The
Greatest Gift of All!](/wiki/A_Colbert_Christmas:_The_Greatest_Gift_of_All! "A
Colbert Christmas: The Greatest Gift of All!")_ , which first aired on 23
November 2008. She played an angel working for Heaven's overloaded phone
(prayer) service. She also accompanied the Disko Bay Expedition of [Cape
Farewell](/wiki/Cape_Farewell,_UK "Cape Farewell, UK").[32] On 20 October
2008, she told [The Canadian Press](/wiki/The_Canadian_Press "The Canadian
Press") that, following the success of her last album, _[The
Reminder](/wiki/The_Reminder "The Reminder")_ , she felt she needed to step
away from the pressures of the music industry to consider her next career move
and "rest for a minute".[33]

In March 2009, it was announced that she would make a guest appearance on the
track "You and I" on [Wilco](/wiki/Wilco "Wilco")'s [seventh
album](/wiki/Wilco_\(The_Album\) "Wilco \(The Album\)").[34]

In 2009, Feist was featured in the [CTV](/wiki/CTV_Television_Network "CTV
Television Network") television film "My Musical Brain" with neuroscientist
and writer [Daniel Levitin](/wiki/Daniel_Levitin "Daniel Levitin"), based on
Levitin's bestselling book [This Is Your Brain on
Music](/wiki/This_Is_Your_Brain_on_Music "This Is Your Brain on Music").

Feist collaborated with Brooklyn band [Grizzly
Bear](/wiki/Grizzly_Bear_\(Band\) "Grizzly Bear \(Band\)") on the song
"Service Bell" for the AIDS charity the [Red Hot
Organization](/wiki/Red_Hot_Organization "Red Hot Organization"). This song
appears on Red Hot's album _[Dark Was the Night](/wiki/Dark_Was_the_Night
"Dark Was the Night")_ , and she joined the band in June 2009 during their
Toronto show to sing this song and contribute backing vocals to the song "Two
Weeks." She also collaborated with [Ben Gibbard](/wiki/Ben_Gibbard "Ben
Gibbard") on a cover of [Vashti Bunyan](/wiki/Vashti_Bunyan "Vashti Bunyan")'s
"[Train Song](/wiki/Train_Song_\(Vashti_Bunyan_song\) "Train Song \(Vashti
Bunyan song\)")" for the same _[Dark Was the Night](/wiki/Dark_Was_the_Night
"Dark Was the Night")_ album.

In June 2009, she re-joined [Broken Social Scene](/wiki/Broken_Social_Scene
"Broken Social Scene") at a [North by Northeast](/wiki/North_by_Northeast
"North by Northeast") performance celebrating the launch of the band's
biography entitled _[This Book Is Broken](/wiki/This_Book_Is_Broken "This Book
Is Broken")_ , in which she is prominently featured. This contradicted various
rumors saying that it was unlikely Feist would ever play with the band again;
this was the first of several appearances with BSS. She performed with Broken
Social Scene during their concert of 11 July 2009 at [Toronto's Harbourfront
Centre](/wiki/Harbourfront_Centre,_Toronto "Harbourfront Centre, Toronto"),
singing and playing guitar through most of the concert,[35] as well as
performing a medley of her solo songs with Kevin Drew and his solo songs. The
concert was filmed by director Bruce Macdonald and released as _[This Movie Is
Broken](/wiki/This_Movie_Is_Broken "This Movie Is Broken")_. She sings on
Broken Social Scene's most recent album _[Forgiveness Rock
Record](/wiki/Forgiveness_Rock_Record "Forgiveness Rock Record")_. She
performed with the band again in June 2010 on Olympic Island, and at the Sound
Academy in Toronto on 9 and 10 December 2010.

Feist joined [Beck](/wiki/Beck "Beck"), Wilco, [Jamie
Lidell](/wiki/Jamie_Lidell "Jamie Lidell") and [James
Gadson](/wiki/James_Gadson "James Gadson") in a Los Angeles studio covering
[Skip Spence](/wiki/Skip_Spence "Skip Spence")'s
_[Oar](/wiki/Oar_\(Skip_Spence_album\) "Oar \(Skip Spence album\)")_ as part
of Beck's Record Club series, with videos appearing on Beck's website
beginning November 2009.[36]

She also contributed vocals on _Constant Companion_ the second album from
Canadian songwriter [Doug Paisley](/wiki/Doug_Paisley "Doug Paisley"). Feist
sings on the tracks "What I Saw" and the duet "Don't Make Me Wait". The album
was released 12 October 2010.

Her song "[Limit to Your Love](/wiki/Limit_to_Your_Love "Limit to Your Love")"
was covered by British post-dubstep artist [James
Blake](/wiki/James_Blake_\(musician\) "James Blake \(musician\)") and later
remixed as a dubstep track by [Benny Benassi](/wiki/Benny_Benassi "Benny
Benassi") and played to high acclaim at the 2011 Ultra Music Festival.

On 7 July 2011, Feist with [Radiohead](/wiki/Radiohead "Radiohead")'s [Colin
Greenwood](/wiki/Colin_Greenwood "Colin Greenwood"),
[Air](/wiki/Air_\(French_band\) "Air \(French band\)")'s Nicolas Godin, [The
Hotrats](/wiki/The_Hotrats "The Hotrats") and [Soap&Skin](/wiki/Soap%26Skin
"Soap&Skin") performed [The Velvet Underground](/wiki/The_Velvet_Underground
"The Velvet Underground") and [Nico](/wiki/Nico "Nico")'s ["Femme
Fatale"](/wiki/Femme_Fatale_\(song\) "Femme Fatale \(song\)") at an all-star
gig "The Velvet Underground Revisited" which took place in [Cité de la
Musique](/wiki/Cit%C3%A9_de_la_Musique "Cité de la Musique"), Paris.[37][38]

Her album _[Metals](/wiki/Metals_\(album\) "Metals \(album\)")_ was released
on 30 September 2011. Collaborators include [Valgeir
Sigurðsson](/wiki/Valgeir_Sigur%C3%B0sson "Valgeir Sigurðsson"), [Chilly
Gonzales](/wiki/Chilly_Gonzales "Chilly Gonzales"), and [Mocky](/wiki/Mocky
"Mocky").[39] The album received widespread acclaim from [music
critics](/wiki/Music_criticism "Music criticism"). It achieved an overall
rating of 7.6/10 at[40] [AnyDecentMusic?](/wiki/AnyDecentMusic%3F
"AnyDecentMusic?") based on 32 reviews.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Feist_Coachella_2012_1.jpg/220px-
Feist_Coachella_2012_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Feist_Coachella_2012_1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Feist_Coachella_2012_1.jpg "Enlarge")

At Coachella, 2012

In 2012, Feist plans to cover a song from the progressive metal band
[Mastodon](/wiki/Mastodon_\(band\) "Mastodon \(band\)"), with Mastodon also
covering Feist, and release both songs on a split 7" on [Record Store
Day](/wiki/Record_Store_Day "Record Store Day").[41] They also released a
crossfading interactive video for the song 'A Commotion'.[5]

Feist also has a cameo in the 2011 movie _[The
Muppets](/wiki/The_Muppets_\(film\) "The Muppets \(film\)")_.

In 2012, she wrote the song "Fire in the Water" exclusively for the film _[The
Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part
2](/wiki/The_Twilight_Saga:_Breaking_Dawn_-_Part_2 "The Twilight Saga:
Breaking Dawn - Part 2")_. The song was played when Edward and Bella are
intimate in their cottage, and has been well received by critics.

Her song "The Water" was covered on American jazz violinist [Zach
Brock](/w/index.php?title=Zach_Brock&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zach Brock \(page
does not exist\)")'s 2012 album _Almost Never Was_.

On 14 January 2013, it was announced Feist would headline, along with
labelmate [Broken Social Scene](/wiki/Broken_Social_Scene "Broken Social
Scene"), the Arts & Crafts Field Trip Music Festival to commemorate the tenth
anniversary of [Arts & Crafts](/wiki/Arts_%26_Crafts_Productions "Arts &
Crafts Productions").[42]

### _Look at What the Light Did Now_
(2013-present)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Feist_\(singer\)&action=edit&section=9&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Look at What the Light Did Now \(2013-present\)")]

In September 2010, Feist announced through her website the release of a
documentary film about the creative process of making of _The Reminder_ ,
called _[Look at What the Light Did Now](/wiki/Look_at_What_the_Light_Did_Now
"Look at What the Light Did Now")_.[43] It was directed by Canadian film
director Anthony Seck and was shot on [Super 8 mm film](/wiki/Super_8_mm_film
"Super 8 mm film"). The film was released on DVD in December 2010, and a
limited series of screenings were conducted including a Toronto screening at
the Royal Ontario Museum, which featured a post-film interview of Feist by
[George Stroumboulopoulos](/wiki/George_Stroumboulopoulos "George
Stroumboulopoulos").

The film focuses on the recording of _The Reminder_ as well as the development
of the tour through puppetry and projection. The film includes interviews with
band member [Afie Jurvanen](/wiki/Bahamas_\(musician\) "Bahamas
\(musician\)"); producer [Chilly Gonzales](/wiki/Chilly_Gonzales "Chilly
Gonzales"); Broken Social Scene bandmates [Kevin Drew](/wiki/Kevin_Drew "Kevin
Drew") and [Andrew Whiteman](/wiki/Andrew_Whiteman "Andrew Whiteman"); and
video director [Patrick Daughters](/wiki/Patrick_Daughters "Patrick
Daughters").

Bonus materials on the DVD include "This One Jam", an early performance of
Feist with Gonzales at Trash Club; live performances from the Reminder tour;
and two short films: "The Water" starring Feist and "Departures" starring
Kevin Drew and based on an idea by Feist. A CD is also included that contains
the documentary soundtrack (tracks from _The Reminder_ re-interpreted and
performed by Gonzales), live performances by Feist, as well as two versions of
the title track, "Look at What the Light Did Now", one of which was recorded
as a duet with the song's writer, American musician [Kyle
Field](/wiki/Kyle_Field_\(musician\) "Kyle Field \(musician\)").

In April 2017, Feist released _[Pleasure](/wiki/Pleasure_\(Feist_album\)
"Pleasure \(Feist album\)")_ , preceding it with the release of the title
track "Pleasure" as a single in March 2017.[44] On April 27, 2017 she
introduced the album (a day ahead of its release) at Trinity St. Paul,
Toronto, before an adoring crowd. She performed the entire content of the
album (in reverse order) as well as some of her earlier work including, "I
Feel It All".
